pulls.title: Initial set of requirements
pulls.author: yaroslavros
pulls.body: As discussed on the call, here is my suggestion for the spec requirements.

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body:
> 1. I suggest we clarify that these requirements are primarily to enable dual certificates (post-quantum and traditional) and not to enable other use cases like multi-identity certs.

As mentioned above - I agree with a caveat that mechanism should be extendable to other use cases in the future.

> 2. We may want to clarify on the need to do atomic validation (i.e., if either cert validation fails, authentication fails).

Fully agree. Though is it a part of requirements to the design or should this be simply a part of the spec? I suggest opening an issue to track this.

> 3. we may want to add a requirement about how key usage and extended key usage extensions in certs should be handled in the dual cert scenario, because dual certs with different key usages could create issues.

This is an interesting problem to explore. Ideally only key usage and extended key usage that peer matters should be checked - everything else is just noise. Or do you think key usage/extended key usage MUST exactly match even if given usage is irrelevant in given situation?

For example, should a client presenting one certificate with just "Client Authentication" EKU and another with both "Client Authentication" EKU and "Server Authentication" EKU be allowed by a server or blocked simply on the grounds of the irrelevant "Server Authentication" EKU being inconsistent in the provided certificates?

> 4. we may want to clarify on how clients should behave if one of the certificates is revoked ?

Again, this seems to be part of the spec, not requirement for the design. Please open an issue to track.

reviews.author: tireddy2
reviews.body:
Thanks Yaroslav, this is a good start. My initial comments below:

1. I suggest we clarify that these requirements are primarily to enable dual certificates (post-quantum and traditional) and not to enable other use cases like multi-identity certs. 
2. We may want to clarify on the need to do atomic validation (i.e., if either cert validation fails, authentication fails).
3. we may want to add a requirement about how key usage and extended key usage extensions in certs should be handled in the dual cert scenario, because dual certs with different key usages could create issues.
4. we may want to clarify on how clients should behave if one of the certificates is revoked ?

comments.body: Attested TLS does not use dual certificates, please see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-fossati-tls-exported-attestation/
I suggest we restrict the scope of traditional and PQ certificates for now.

I am not an expert on attested TLS. I was under the impression that a common pattern is expected to be for endpoint to present two certificates - one secure boot attestation and another regular hostname certificate. Am I missing something?

Would `Future expandability to Non-PQC Multi-Cert Use cases` work better for you? I don't want to design yet another construct for other situations when a peer might need to present two chains. Or more than two chains.
I am not familiar with any such proposal being discussed in the expat BoF, https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/bofreq-fossati-tls-exported-attestation-expat/
Yes, works for me.

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body: Closing this one for now. Will revisit this topic after removing the flag as discussed

```suggestion
To mitigate these impacts, deployments can apply certificate chain optimization techniques, such as those described in {{Section 6.1 of ?PQ-RECOMMEND=I-D.reddy-uta-pqc-app}}, to minimize transmission overhead and improve handshake robustness.
```

```suggestion
The context string is used as input to the data over which the signature is computed, consistent with the `CertificateVerify` construction defined in {{Section 4.4.3 of TLS}}. The first signature uses the same context string as in the TLS 1.3 specification:
```
I am not sure if I agree with this addition. Let's keep applicability to its own scope section. I hope WG will chime in here.

```suggestion
Certificate chains must be validated independently, including trust anchors, certificate usage constraints, expiration, and revocation status. Operators MUST ensure that revocation checking, such as using OCSP or CRLs, is consistently applied to both chains to prevent reliance on revoked credentials.
```

I suppose MUST is appropriate here.

I suggest dropping roots part here as in practical cases PQ and classical roots are very likely to be distinct.
As discussed on the call today, please remove this addition - it will be addressed by removing the `dual_certificate_required` flag.
